text:
ANITA: Professor Hinds studies
the effect of technology

on teams collaboration
and innovation.

She's conducted
extensive research

on the dynamics of
cross-boundary work teams

and particularly those
spanning national borders.

So welcome to folks
all over the world.
Professor Hinds --

Pam also has a body of research
on human robot interaction

in the work environment and the
dynamics of human robot teams.

And most recently, Pam has been
looking at the changing nature

of work in the face of emerging
technologies, including

the nature of coordination
and open innovation,

and changes in work
and organizations

resulting from 3D printing
and the work of data analysts.

Before we begin for our
audience, please remember you

can enter in a
question at any time,

and I do encourage you to
submit your questions earlier
during the webinar.

So don't wait until
the last minute.

Go ahead and put
them in and we'll

go ahead and take a
look at those as we're
going through the webinar.
With that, let's begin.
Pam, welcome.

So delighted to have you with
us today, and let's go ahead
and get started.

Pam, would you discuss
what you think of --
what is digital transformation?

PAMELA HINDS: Yeah,
great question.

And it's kind of a
complicated question

because there are a lot
of different definitions

that are floating out there
and people think of it
in different ways.

And it's different in
different contexts,

but I think that
generally, and this

is the way I think of
digital transformation,

is a radical reimagining
of how an organization uses

technology, particularly
emerging kinds

of technology to fundamentally
change their business models
and business performance.

And that includes rethinking,
products, services, processes,

and includes emerging
technologies like AI,

machine learning, the
expansion of data,

the internet of things,
robotics, social media
platforms, and so forth.

So a host of different kinds
of emerging technologies,

but the key for me
in the definition

is that it's not about
incremental change.

It's really this
radical reimagining

of what we are delivering in
terms of products and services

to our customers and
how we are operating--

what our internal processes
are for delivering those.
ANITA: Great.
Thanks.

With that in mind, you do
talk a lot about culture.

Why is that important to
digital transformation?

PAMELA HINDS: Yeah, I think it's
critically important because, I

mean there's a lot of
evidence at this point

that organizations that
successfully achieve

digital transformation undergo
significant cultural change

or they're a new
organization that

has a culture that
aligns with what

is required to
operate effectively,

and I'll go into
more detail on that.

But the bottom
line is it can't be

done using existing processes,
systems, and structures
from a decade or more ago.

And part of the reason
for that is because it
requires continual innovation--

continual meaning that it's
not just a skunkworks operation

that comes up with
a new great idea,

but it's something that
an organization needs

to attend to on a really
constant basis in order

to stay up on these rapid
changes in the technology
and in the business environment.

And that means that there
are fundamental changes

in the organization that are
required for organizations

to do this because
historically, we just

haven't had to move that quickly
and be that externally focused.

And one of the things
that people ask is, well,

isn't it really about
getting good digital talent,

knowing about
these technologies,

and being able to
use them effectively
in these transformations?
Absolutely.

That is a necessary, but
not a sufficient condition

for digital
transformation because you

can get overly
focused, and we see

organizations do this all
the time get overly focused

on the digital piece,
the technology piece,

and not on the
transformation piece.

And we're really talking about
again this more fundamental

radical change to the
way that we do business.
ANITA: Great.
Thank you for that.

You know, you talk about the
characteristics and culture

needed for digital
transformation,

and I'm going to put up a
slide that you and I had talked

about that we wanted
to discuss as part

of this fireside chat
and it's kind of-- it's
the integral component.

And you go into this in
your course in the program.

Can you talk about
the characteristics
of digital culture?

This diagram, in
particular, and how

it's fundamental for
every transformation.
PAMELA HINDS: Yeah, absolutely.

So the way that this
diagram came about

is I read broadly about the
digital transformations that

were successful and
were unsuccessful
over, say, decade long period.

And there's quite a
bit that's written

there are a number of really
good books that talk about--

that provide these
examples of organizations

that have been able to
do this successfully.

And what I did was I distilled
these into the five elements

that you see here
on this diagram.

One that's right in the center
is being customer-centric.

So we'll describe
that in a minute,

but also being nimble
and fast, really

focusing on voracious
learning or a learning based

culture, unbounded
collaboration, and appetite
for risk.

So those are the five that
you see in this diagram.

Customer-centric is in
the middle of the diagram

because all of
these capabilities--

nimble and fast, voracious
learning, and so forth--

are employed in service of
providing customer value.

Oftentimes, through these
new business models,

but also new products,
services, and so forth.
So it needs to be--

the organizations that
are most successful

really focus first on
what can be provided

to the customer, what needs
are out there that are not yet

being met that can be met
through these transformations.

So that's the
customer-centric piece.
Nimble and fast.

The reason that that's on there
is because the pace of change,

as we are embarking on these
digital transformation,

requires rethinking the
direction that we're
going and pivoting regularly.

We need to be in
a position to be

able to act on new initiatives
without spending a lot of time
retooling and transitioning.

So it's a combination
of innovation and speed
that are required.

And in order to be
nimble and fast,

oftentimes, we need to rethink
our organizational structures.

Oftentimes, our traditional
hierarchical structures

get in the way of being
able to move quickly.

They're designed for
reliability, not for speed.

And the same thing with our
internal processes, approval

processes, and so forth
can get in our way

of being able to take advantage
of these opportunities rapidly.

The next one is
voracious learning.

And basically what
this means is having

a culture in the
organization that's really
about learning and curiosity.

In order to drive new
knowledge creation,

you need to have people willing
to go out and figure things
out.

Not just willing to, but
passionate about going

and learning new things and
thinking in new ways as opposed
to--

again, a very
traditional organization

would be focused on hiring
people who know what--

who have the expertise
that you need and then
exploiting that expertise.

In this new environment of
the digital transformation,

we don't necessarily
know what it

is that is going
to be important,

the expertise that's
going to be required.

And it's going to be new
expertise that is developing.

So it's really
important that we have

a workforce that is
excited about and supported
in learning.

In terms of unbounded
collaboration,

what I'm talking about there
is being willing to work--

willing to and
incentivized for working

across boundaries
that are traditional
within an organization.

So having cross-functional
groups working together more
actively.

Sometimes, it means working
outside of the organization

where you need to have access
to expertise that doesn't exist
within the organization itself.

And this is important to
digital transformation

because these complex
digital offerings often

require bringing together very
different kinds of expertise,

different kinds of
technology, and where

we may have historically been
able to do that in tandem,

where you've got one
group that works on it,

hands over to another group that
hands over to another group.

And there's this
iterative process.

That way, that's just
not fast enough anymore.

So what it requires is
bringing all the right people

into the room at the
beginning and working
through these ideas.

And also, that's
a way to come up

with really new and novel
ideas if people are really

building on the knowledge
and expertise of others.

And then finally, we
have appetite for risk.

And what I mean by that
is an organization that

has a culture as
well as processes,

incentive systems,
structures, and so forth that

encourage and
support risk taking.
Why is that important?

Well, it's because
people won't take risks.
They won't innovate.

They won't try
new things if they

are afraid that they are going
to be punished in some way

or embarrassed in some way
within the organization.

They're going to take a
route that is safer for them.

So it's really
important that people

feel like that it's
actually a good thing

to try new things
even if they fail.

What's important,
though, about this

is that it doesn't mean
that everybody can just
make mistakes in their work.

Amy Edmondson, who's a
professor at Harvard,

talks about
preventable failures.

These are things where we
know how to do it right,
and we just got sloppy.

That's not the kind of risk
that I'm talking about.

I'm talking about what she
calls intelligent failures

at the frontier, and
these are failures

that provide new knowledge
to the individuals

and organization and are
good for the organization.

They're actually
learning opportunities

for the organization,
and particularly in cases

when we actually don't
know the answer in advance.

We don't know whether
or not this new solution
is going to work.

We don't know whether
or not there's really
going to be a market for it.

So how can we experiment,
fail quickly, and move on?

So I know I spoke
a lot here, Anita.

But kind of in summary
to your question,

I think that digital
transformation

is as much about the
transformation as the digital,

and the transformation piece
requires really rethinking

organizational culture,
structures, and systems

in the way that people think
about their work and work
together.
ANITA: Excellent.
Thanks, Pam.

And thanks for going deep
in some of these topics.

So really appreciate
you expanding
on some of these ideas.
Next question.
And this is more of a--

say somebody is not a digital
transformation leader.

They're not leading
an initiative,

or they're a member, but they're
not necessarily the leader,

or they'd like to
learn, to get involved,

or make change in
their organization.

So why is that
important to learn

about digital
transformation, even

if you're not going
to be the leader,
but you will be a participant?
PAMELA HINDS: Yeah.
Now that's a great question.

And my answer is
that nobody's immune.

Even if you're not leading in
digital transformation today,

you're likely to
be impacted by it.
And if not today, sometime soon.

According to the
World Economic Forum,

no industry is going
to be able to avoid
digital transformation.

So if you're thinking that,
well, I'm in an industry
that it's not going to affect.
Ultimately, it probably will.

Or if you're in a role that you
don't think will be affected

or you'll be called
on to respond
to digital transformation.

You know it's
possible, but there's

a really high likelihood that
it will affect every role
throughout the organization.

And one of the
reasons is if you go

back to what I was talking
about before in terms

of the cultural
change, that's just not

just in one part of
the organization.

The cultural change has to
span the entire organization.

So it's useful to
learn, I think,

about digital
transformation so that you

understand why the organization
is shifting in the way
that it is.

And actually being able
to support and help

the organization in doing
that, even if you're not

right now on the front
line of some kind

of digital transformation in
terms of a particular product
or service.

As I mentioned, even
industries that are typically

thought about as
being low-tech will be

and are experiencing
radical changes.
So it's important to be ready.

I actually, over
the last few months,

have been spending
time at dairy farms.

And dairy farms one of the new
technologies that's coming in

is new robotic milking machines,
and they're just amazing.

The cows actually choose
when they want to be milked

and they go into this
system, and the system
is complete with sensors.

There's a dashboard that
the dairy men or women

can use to monitor the health,
the milk production, and so
forth of their cows.

It'll flag whether
or not there is a cow
that they should go check on.

And they can do that from
anywhere on an iPad these days.

So even agriculture
which we think

of as being pretty low-tech,
there are amazing things.

That are happening and happening
rapidly and really transforming

what it means to work
in those industries.

The other thing I would
say is that because

successful digital
transformation

requires the significant
overhaul of most organizational
cultures.

As I said earlier,
most employees

are going to be affected,
at least to some extent.

And if you understand
those requirements,

you can actually
position yourself

on the front end
of those changes

and help your organization
instead of being surprised
and potentially lagging behind.

And one of the
things I'll say too,

Anita, is, in our digital
transformation program what

we've done is
identified four courses

that we think are really
important for learners

to start with, that provide,
I think, a nice coverage

of the types of changes that
are needed in organizations

for transformation ways to
think about the different kinds

of technological advances
that might make sense

for particular organizations
or contexts or applications.

And, importantly, how to
effectively lead these efforts.
So those courses are--

they all start
with this X-D-G-T.
I'm going to ignore that.

First one is number 100,
and that is foundations
of digital transformation.

And that goes into
more detail on what

I was talking about earlier
in terms of those five

different aspects of
the foundational culture
that an organization needs.

The next one I'll
mention is 224,

which is building an
AI-enabled organization.

And this is a really, I think,
fun course because it looks

across a broad
swath of industries

at the different ways that
AI can actually enable
new products and services.

I find that course to be
really kind of inspirational.

The other one is 223, which
is building a product platform
strategy to accelerate growth.

So, in this course, we really
look at products and kind

of the traditional product
strategy and platforms

and how you bring those together
in a way that is really aligned

with what you're
trying to accomplish

and what the strategy
is for the organization.

And Professor
Eisner teaches that,

brings in lots of nice
case studies, and so forth.

And then the last
one I'll mention

is in the fourth one
on the list is 111.

And this course is
systems leadership,

managing uncertainty
in the digital age.

And this very much
focuses on how

to be a more effective
leader when things are more
complex and more uncertain.

So that's one that everybody
can benefit particularly
in this day and age.
ANITA: Thank you.

And thanks for talking
about the core courses.

That's something new that
we've added to the program

to give our learners
or customers a learning

journey that would be
appropriate for them

depending upon where
they are in their career,

and whether they're focused
more on a managerial path
or technical track.

So thank you for
expanding on that
why we pick those four courses.

And then I also do want to
mention that, on your screens,

for those of you who
are with us today,

you can also see
another opportunity.

This is one of our
first opportunities

to invite learners, customers
to come to the Stanford campus.

In late January, we're
hosting a course on campus

where you can learn from
digital transformation

our faculty members that
teach in this program.

And you can learn
more by clicking on--

there's a link there
for the program, which

is called Innovation
Strategy in a Digital World,

and our customer service can
answer any additional questions
you might have.
We have about 5 minutes left.

And so, I would
love it if you would

answer a question from one
of our guests here today.

This is, how do you overcome
organizational resistance
to transformation?

And we know this one comes
up a lot, especially when

the folks in charge might not be
aligned to support that change.

And you know, you
talk about risk,

not only risk from the
people that are actually

going to make the change,
implement the changes

whether it's
managerial, process,

technology, but the
executives that have to be
comfortable with that risk.

Can you talk a little
bit about that?
PAMELA HINDS: Yeah.

I mean, that's hard because,
for the type of change that I'm

talking about, it really
requires high-level leadership

if you're going to change your
organizational structures,

if you're going to change
your organizational culture,

if you're going to encourage
and not punish risk.

And that really
does trickle down

from the top of
the organization.

In the absence of
that, somebody who

is sort of leading from
the middle, if you will,

one of the things that
has worked really well
is what we call small wins.

And that is doing
something more locally

to prove out the importance
of doing this so that--

you know, because,
oftentimes, the reason

that people are
resistant is because they
are concerned about the risk.

They're not convinced that
it really is important

or is going to be successful
or the organization
can do it effectively.

So to be able to prove
that out in small ways

with the resources
that you have available

is a good way to get
people's attention,

and then you can publicize
those small wins.

And hopefully, over time,
although, hopefully,

quickly too because
things are moving quickly,

get more support from
leadership in the organization.

And the other thing too
is to look for leaders
that are supportive.

Even if there is
some resistance,

there probably other leaders in
the organization that get it.

So working with them as
allies, as a team that

can kind of develop and
champion these small wins
and these changes.

ANITA: I'm going to try and
squeeze in one more question.

And what do you
foresee as a future
of digital transformation?
PAMELA HINDS: Oh, yeah.

So that's the
million-dollar question,

and I wish I had a
crystal ball to predict,

but in terms of
the details of it,

it's hard because
these are innovations,

and we don't know right
by the nature of what

we're talking about in
terms of transformation.
We don't know.

But what I can say
with confidence

is that we can pretty much
guarantee that there will

be continued disruptions to
organizations and to industries

driven by these advances
and technologies

and these innovative
new business models,

products, services,
and so forth that

capitalize on those
technologies and those advances.

And that includes everything
that we're seeing out there AI,

machine learning, sensors
digital traceability,

virtual and augmented reality,
smart materials, robotics,
and so on and so forth.

And perhaps most
importantly, the integration

of these technologies
for new products,

services, and processes
within the organization.

So I guess the two
things just summarize

that I would predict is
we're going to see continued

disruptions and we're going to
see more and more integration

of these technologies
in order to affect

the kind of transformation
that we're going to be seeing.
ANITA: Great.
Thank you.
Let's see here.

I'm trying to see if I
could squeeze in one more--

one more minute if you
had to do one last thing.

The few words of why digital
transformation in one minute.

PAMELA HINDS: Why
digital transformation?

Why is it happening,
or why the program?
ANITA: Why the program?
PAMELA HINDS: Yeah.

I guess it would
go back to what I

was saying earlier,
which is this is
an inevitability for all of us.

And it's not-- you
know, even in education
we're experiencing this.
It is pervasive.

And you know, it
is always better

to be in the know and be able to
anticipate some of these things

so that we can get ahead
of them and have an impact

and make a contribution
and potentially

even choose different career
paths depending upon where
we think we can contribute.
ANITA: Fantastic.
Thank you, Pam.

Thank you for that last
impromptu question too.

I want to thank everybody
who joined us today
and your participation.

There will be a
recording of this

that will be shared with
you within a few days.
And thank you again, Pam.

And thank you all for
joining us for this first

of a kind of fireside
chat for the Stanford

digital transformation
program, and I wish you

all a wonderful day and
journey through your career.
Thanks.
PAMELA HINDS: Thank you.
Thank you, Anita.
And thank you, everyone.
